Dear Mr. DeSantis:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
2/27/2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by
another agency the borrowing agency shall have a
record containing all the following: (f) Documentation that
the foster parent has received orientation to the policies
of the borrowing agency.
One of three borrowed home files did not have documentation that orientation was
completed with the foster parents.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(3) When case responsibility changes from 1 child
placing agency to another child placing agency, a
modified service plan must be completed within 30
calendar days of the change in agency responsibility if
no other plan is done within 30 days. The plan must
address why the agency responsibility changed and
whether there are any modifications to existing service
plans.
One of three foster care files did not have a modified service plan completed within
30 days of case transfer.
2

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following area:
• The agency was provided with technical assistance regarding the
requirements of rule 418. The agency was provided with examples of 30-day
abbreviated service plans for case transfers.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• The facility did not request consultation at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during the licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with the CAP is as follows:
The agency renewal inspection was completed on 2/5/24 and the CAP was
approved on 2/28/24. The agency was cited for four violations, none of which were
repeated this year. In the 2023 interim review, 7 violations were cited, none of
which were repeated this year. The agency reported successful implementation of
their 2024 CAP, as is reflected in the current review.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was reviewed and discussed. The chief
administrator reported some challenges with staffing over the last year, due to
staff turnover and some staff leave of absences. However, staff pulled together
and assisted one another to meet goals and serve clients. The chief administrator
reported the agency implemented their previous CAP by updating tools,
processes, and utilizing reminder system for due dates. These activities appeared
to be effective as there were no repeat violations, and few citations.
Financial Overview
The agency’s annual budget and 2024 financial audit were reviewed. No financial
concerns were noted.
Staff Interviews
Two staff were interviewed face-to-face at the agency. Both staff reported being
very happy in their positions. Both staff stated their supervisors were outstanding.
Supervisors were described as being knowledgeable, helpful, and supportive.
Staff stated everyone at the agency works together well and there were no
suggestions for improvement.
3

Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency remains in the same location as previous years. The building has
adequate office space for staff, and visitation and meeting space for children and
families. All case files were stored securely, and the agency maintains a cross
shredder for disposal of confidential information.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There was one identified safety alert.
Safety Alert # 1: The home was observed to be extremely cluttered. The children’s
beds did not have bedding and clothing, toys and various items were strewn about
the bedroom. The kitchen/dining area had several boxes and crates stacked from
the floor to the top of the table. Broken chairs were stacked on top of each other.
The home had an odor of dog urine and feces.
Resolution: The caregiver was provided with clear expectations by the agency to
resolve the safety alert. A follow-up home visit was completed by the foster care
worker and licensing supervisor. The home was observed to be decluttered, the
carpet shampooed, and the beds had clean linens. Photos were provided to DCWL
as verification.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. A corrective action plan is required.
